clinical_study.official_title: Computer-Based Intervention for Victimized Perinatal Women With Mental Illness (Phase 1)

lead_sponsor.agency: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

clinical_study.source: Women and Infants Hospital of Rhode Island

brief_summary.textblock: The study will develop and assess an innovative, high-reach, easily implementable, low-cost computer-delivered intervention (Reach out for a Safe Environment; ROSE Program) that will address known barriers in early identification and intervention with perinatal women with IPV seeking treatment for mental illness.

detailed_description.textblock:
Intimate partner violence (IPV) is a significant social and public health problem among perinatal women. Research suggests that from 21% to 33% of perinatal women report IPV and there is an enormous amount of morbidity associated with IPV. Moreover, IPV places a woman at high risk for several psychiatric disorders, which transforms the perinatal period from an already challenging process into a potentially overwhelming one. Further, IPV and untreated mental illness during the perinatal period pose a dual risk of adverse physical and emotional outcomes for women and their developing fetus/infant. Experts in the field advocate for more IPV screening and intervention to take place among women who are at high-risk for IPV. Given the high rates of IPV among women who seek mental health treatment, mental health clinics compared to other medical settings (e.g. primary care) are more effective sites for focused case finding and intervention. Further, the presence of IPV increases the likelihood of disengagement from treatment, which could compromise the ability of women with IPV to effectively use important shelter and community resources necessary for establishing safety for themselves and their children. A timely intervention might reduce the risk of future IPV, improve treatment utilization, and reduce mental health symptoms. A brief intervention that is designed specifically for the unique needs of perinatal women with IPV seeking mental health treatment provides a tremendous opportunity to intervene with a group of women who are particularly vulnerable and who might be unusually open to making changes to their lives.
The proposed study is the first step towards developing a computer-based brief intervention ("Reach Out for a Safe Environment") that targets intimate partner violence in perinatal women in mental health treatment and constitutes the developmental aims of a larger study. The aims are to perform a small open trial (n = 8) of the Reach Out for a Safe Environment (ROSE) intervention to assess feasibility of recruitment of target population and acceptability of intervention and study procedures. Also, to conduct a randomized controlled pilot study in a sample of 50 perinatal women seeking mental health treatment who screen positive for recent IPV to demonstrate the acceptability and feasibility of the ROSE intervention via participant report of ease of use, helpfulness, and overall satisfaction.
We will collect several measures on the feasibility of the research design, the acceptability of ROSE, and on intervention effects for IPV severity and level of self-care strategies (primary outcomes), motivation and self efficacy (secondary outcomes), and use of recommended mental health treatment services (tertiary outcome). This phase uses a two-group, randomized, controlled design with an initial session for both conditions plus booster session one month later for the intervention condition. The initial intervention session will be conducted close to an intake visit for mental health difficulties, with a booster session within one month following baseline. There will be a 3-month follow up assessment. Assessments and the booster session will be conducted in a private room or at a location that is a convenient location for the woman and one that will provide a confidential, safe, and comfortable environment for the participant.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at baseline, and again three months later
primary_outcome.description: A widely used self-report of behaviors that includes a 30-item scale with 4 subscales that measure severe, combined abuse, emotional abuse, physical abuse, and harassment. The CAS has recently been published in the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention compendium of intimate partner violence measures. Items are presented in a six point format requiring respondents to answer "never", "only once", "several times", "monthly", "weekly" or "daily" in a three month period. The CAS will also be used to assess whether women have engaged in abusive behaviors towards their partners.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at baseline, and again three months later
primary_outcome.description: Includes 15 items that assess the use of strategies suggested to keep victim safe (e.g., hiding money and extra clothing).

primary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at baseline, and again three months later
primary_outcome.description: Assesses the women's effectiveness in obtaining resources from 11 different types of community resources including mental health treatment, church or clergy, health care, legal services, police, or social services.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at baseline, and again three months later
secondary_outcome.description: A 5-item measure, will be modified to assess motivation to increase IPV relationship safety behaviors and has been used successfully in our target population.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Readiness to Change Contemplation Ladder
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessed at baseline, and again three months later
secondary_outcome.description: Modified to assess self-efficacy for change in IPV safety behaviors.

arm_group.description: Participants will receive a 50-minute intervention on the Tablet PC immediately after their baseline assessment and an in-person 30-minute booster session conducted by interventionists within a month after the intervention. Research staff will be on-site and available to ROSE participants if they have questions after the completion of the computer-based session. There will also be a follow-up assessment 3 months after completion of the ROSE program.

Control Condition will consist of a series of questions regarding television show preferences and viewing a brief series of videos of popular entertainers/shows, with subsequent requests for ratings of subjective preference. Participants in this condition will complete a baseline assessment as well as a follow-up assessment 3 months later.

intervention.description: The ROSE Program will be specifically tailored, innovative and relevant to diverse, racial and ethnic perinatal women in a number of ways including the images and content used in the intervention and coordinating study appointments with treatment visits. It will also be tailored on the current IPV risk assessment, pregnancy or postpartum status of each participant, will be designed to reach participants across levels of motivation for change. The content of ROSE will be theory-driven, consistent with the Motivational Interviewing model of behavior, and consistent with the literature on effective interventions that address IPV.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant or postpartum women (up to 6 months after delivery)
- Age 18 or older
- At their intake appointment at The Center for Women's Behavioral Health (WBH) at Women and Infants Hospital (WIH) or already in treatment there
- Endorsed any IPV during the past 12 months as measured by the Woman Abuse Screening Tool (WAST)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to provide informed consent (e.g., due to psychosis, intoxication, or other clear cognitive impairment)
- Inability to understand English (understand the consent form when read aloud and assessments that are narrated by computer)
